title: Bad Judgment and Biden's Pentagon
summary: Colin Kahl is the wrong choice to be chief Defense strategist.. Another Biden nominee with a record of intemperate tweets is at risk of sinking in the Senate, and the press is comparing him to Neera Tanden, the President's withdrawn first pick to lead the Office of Management and Budget. Yet whoever replaces Ms. Tanden is unlikely to change the trajectory of the Biden Administration's progressive policies.

title: An Airbus-Boeing Tariff Truce
summary: Biden deserves credit for limiting harm over the subsidy dispute.. Trade disputes can take years to resolve, and even friendly nations cause each other needless pain in the meantime. title: Finance Chiefs Look to Price Increases to Offset Higher Commodities Costs

title: Cathie Wood's ARK Faces Test as Tech Rally Cools
summary: Big bets on unprofitable companies are causing trouble for the star stock picker's funds. The stock market's swift turn against technology and other growth stocks has handed star stock picker Cathie Wood and her firm, ARK Investment Management LLC, their toughest test yet.

title: CDC Says Vaccinated People Can Gather Privately Without Masks
summary: New guidelines direct fully inoculated people to wear masks and observe social distancing in public. People who are fully vaccinated against the new coronavirus can gather privately in small groups without masks or physical distancing, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said, relaxing safety guidelines for inoculated individuals under some circumstances.

title: Tax Forgiveness for Student Loan Forgiveness
summary: Democrats grease the budget wheels for writing off debt by Biden decree.. title: Philadelphia's Union Thuggery
summary: The feds allege a powerful labor chief engaged in extortion.. Good luck building in Philadelphia without paying off Big Labor. title: Japan Can Lift the Covid Cloud From the (Delayed) 2020 Olympics
summary: Participants will be subject to strict controls-most of which vaccination has rendered unnecessary.. But it will require a 90-degree turn for Tokyo to mount what it calls "an Olympics to unite the world."

title: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Korea?
summary: Pyongyang shrugs off sticks and turns up its nose at carrots. Biden has few options.. The closing section ("Spinning the World Under the Axis of Sovereignty and Justice") hails Mr. Kim's summits with leaders including Donald Trump, Xi Jinping, Vladimir Putin and South Korea's President Moon Jae-in. Summing it up, the authors gush that "there has never been a time when all the world has been this focused on our people's greatness and dignity in our 5,000-year history."

summary: For criticizing H.R.1, he is accused of spreading Donald Trump's 'big lie.'. That didn't last long.

title: 'Reclaiming Patriotism in an Age of Extremes' Review: Competing Loyalties
summary: Today both nationalism and cosmopolitanism are testing the very deﬁnition of allegiance to one's country.. Almost two decades ago, I received a letter from a young man serving in AmeriCorps, the civilian national service program. At the time, I headed the agency that ran the program. After 9/11, President Bush had called on Americans to serve their country, to "fight evil by doing good," as he put it, and he mentioned joining AmeriCorps. The response almost overwhelmed the AmeriCorps budget.

title: Apax Partners Seeks $1.5 Billion for Second Midmarket Digital Fund
summary: The firm expects to hold a first close for Apax Digital II LP in May or June. Buyout firm Apax Partners is pitching its second digital fund focused on midmarket technology companies just weeks after collecting $11 billion for its latest main investment pool.

summary: Spotify announced it would begin offering higher-resolution sound. But will you really be able to hear the difference, or care?.

title: The Pandemic Is Prompting Many to Delay or Abandon Plans to Have Children
summary: Demographers warn the baby bust is unlikely to be temporary. A year into the pandemic, early data and surveys point to a baby bust in many advanced economies from the U.S. to Europe to East Asia. A combination of health and economic crises is prompting many people to delay or abandon plans to have children.

title: Who'll Be Left After the Seuss Cancellation?
summary: Antonio Gramsci, a co-founder of the Italian Communist Party, wrote that to capture power you don't need an armed revolution, you simply need to undermine the existing culture.. Regarding Michael Saltsman's "The Next Cancellation Target: Dr. Seuss," op-ed, March 2): Dr. Seuss is yet another victim of the so-called "liberals" and "progressives." The book burners and totalitarians in waiting continue to be carelessly portrayed by the centrist and conservative media as "liberals" and "progressives." Today's liberals and progressives' calculated linguistic somersault is designed to pigeonhole their opponents. After all who can be against social justice and in favor of racism?

title: Rubio Calls for Rare-Earth Industrial Policy
summary: Today, the U.S. is largely dependent on China's government-backed rare-earth manufacturing industry.. Rare-earth minerals are integral to many of America's most important advanced manufacturing industries. Hard drives, electric vehicles, critical defense technologies and countless other consumer devices all require them. Today, the U.S. is largely dependent on China's government-backed rare-earth manufacturing industry. Such a reliance poses serious national and economic security concerns. Yet your editorial ("Rare Truths About China's Rare Earths," March 4) plays down the risks and oversimplifies what is needed to restart and sustain a domestic rare-earth mining industry, suggesting the failure to do so boils down to environmental regulations.

title: The Covid Unemployment Aid Bonanza Is Killing Us
summary: Our job postings on multiple online platforms, social media and the local newspapers return zero interested applicants week after week.. Regarding Mitt Romney's "Biden's Stimulus Bill Is a $1.9 Trillion Clunker" (op-ed, Feb. 24) and Casey B. Mulligan and Stephen Moore's "How Many Jobs Will the 'Stimulus' Kill?" (op-ed, Feb. 26): The stimulus is indeed throwing sand in the gears of many restaurant owners. While I applaud Congress's intention to support individuals in need, this is best done without disincentivizing work and strangling small businesses. Although our two family-owned restaurants in Vermont pay employees well above the minimum wage, since the first $600 stimulus checks were mailed last spring, hiring has been nearly impossible. Our job postings on multiple online platforms, social media and the local newspapers return zero interested applicants week after week. These are flexible jobs, with advancement opportunity and a reasonable wage. In speaking with other restaurant owners around the country, I've found they universally report the same problem-too many jobs, not enough candidates.

title: U.S. Grants New Deportation Protection for Venezuelans
summary: Temporary Protected Status designation offers work permits, deportation relief for at least 18 months. title: Political Propaganda, Race And Public-Health Scares
summary: T.D. Jakes reports that black Americans think the Covid vaccine is a reprise of the Tuskegee syphilis experiment. None of this surprises me, but then again I grew up in the U.S.S.R.. T.D. Jakes reports that black Americans think the Covid vaccine is a reprise of the Tuskegee syphilis experiment ("Prayer and Science Led Me to the Vaccine," Houses of Worship, Feb. 26). Of course they do. For months liberals have been shouting that whites are guilty of "supremacy" and that minorities should get vaccines before anyone else. And just like the syphilis experiment, it costs nothing to participate. Can we really blame black Americans for mistaking a racially prioritized program for, well, racism?

title: How We Calculated Electricity-Rate Comparisons
summary: The Wall Street Journal investigated how retail choice has worked out for residential power customers. In more than a dozen states, many residents can choose the provider of their electricity. In most of those states, residents who used to have only one choice for their electricity provider-a traditional utility-now could choose between sticking with their utility for full service or shopping around and buying their power from a retail energy marketer, with their utility delivering it for a fee. Texas went even further, requiring nearly 60% of its residents to buy electricity on the open market, with no option to remain with a traditional utility. The marketers in that state charge for all facets of the electricity, including delivery.

Florida Republicans Pitch State as Model for Expanding GOP Appeal
summary: The state is a rare battleground where former President Donald Trump improved on his 2016 performance; local Republicans feel emboldened. LAKE CITY, Fla.-Florida Republicans are pitching themselves as a model for Republicans across the country on how to hold elections, handle the coronavirus pandemic and expand the GOP's appeal to a broad swath of voters by emphasizing freedom and casting Democrats as socialist.
